abstract: The effect of plasma electrolytic oxidation (PEO) on the fatigue of AZ61 magnesium alloy has been investigated under high cycle conditions in air and 3.5% NaCl solution. PEO employed an alkaline pyrophosphate-silicate-fluoride electrolyte, with an offset square waveform, a frequency of 50Hz, and current density of 130mAcm-2. The PEO treatment led to reductions in the fatigue limit by 38% in air and by 56% in 3.5% NaCl solution. The reduction of the fatigue limit is attributed to cracking of the coating, roughness of the alloy/coating interface, corrosion and influences of Al-Mn particles. © 2014 The Authors.

author_highlights.sentence: Plasma electrolytic oxidation coatings formed on AZ61Mg alloy in alkaline electrolyte.
Coating reduced fatigue limit in air by 38% and by 56% in NaCl solution.
Cracks initiate in bare alloy at Al–Mn particles and regions of corrosion.
Initiation in coated alloy in air assisted by crack and roughness.
Initiation in coated alloy in NaCl solution promoted by corrosion under coating.

body_text.sentence: The degradation of fatigue properties of the AZ61 alloy after PEO treatment is probably due to a combination of factors, including stress concentration, that results from cracks in the coating layer [22], the roughness of the alloy/coating interface [22], and corrosion beneath the coating, which enhance the stress locally in the alloy surface and assist crack initiation, leading to the higher number of initiation sites observed on the coated specimens compared with the bare alloy.

body_text.sentence: PEO was carried out in 1 dm−3 of stirred electrolyte in a double-walled glass cell, with water cooling that maintained the electrolyte temperature in the range 293–303 K.
body_text.title: Material and PEO treatment

body_text.sentence: A representative example of the final fracture is shown for a coated specimen tested in air at a stress amplitude of 300 MPa (Fig. 11(b)).
body_text.title: Fractographic analysis

body_text.sentence: The flat surfaces of specimens (i) were ground to a 1200 grit finish using SiC paper and cleaned in acetone in an ultrasonic bath.
